intro: Dalea polygonoides, commonly known as the plains false indigo, is a flowering plant native to the central and southern United States. It is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its upright growth habit and clusters of blue to violet pea-like flowers. The plant has small, pinnately compound leaves and produces pod-like fruits that contain several seeds. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in prairies and open woodlands. Dalea polygonoides is valued for its ornamental appeal and its ability to fix nitrogen, benefiting soil fertility.
